content_sections.Module Description:
This module continues the study of real analysis from the previous semester and will introduce you to another important area of pure mathematics – group theory.

Real Analysis is fundamental to Mathematics as it is the reason why Calculus works. You will learn about limits of functions and continuity before moving on to study the formal definitions of the derivative and integral of a function, and for what sorts of functions these actually make sense. This then leads to the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, which proves that integration and differentiation are essentially inverses of each other.

Group Theory is the study of symmetry, treated in an abstract way which then allows for application in many situations in Mathematics and beyond. You will start by developing a list of axioms for what a group should be, and then study the implications of these axioms: for example, what one can deduce about the possible sizes of subgroups (Lagrange’s Theorem), how to define functions between groups in sensible way (homomorphisms), when different groups are really the same (isomorphism), and how to use known groups to build new ones (product and quotient groups). Throughout, you will see many examples.

Computation and modelling are essential skills for the modern mathematician. While many applied problems are amenable to analytic methods, many require some numerical computation to complete the solution. The synthesis of these two approaches can provide deep insight into highly complex mathematical ideas.

This module will introduce you to the art of mathematical modelling, and train you in the computer programming skills needed to perform numerical computations. You will be introduced to the Python programming language and study algorithms for problems such as root finding. A particular focus of mathematical modelling is classical mechanics, which describes the motion of solid bodies. Central to this is Newton’s second law of motion, which states that a mass will accelerate at a rate proportional to the force imposed upon it. This leads to an ordinary differential equation to be solved for the velocity and position of the mass. In the simplest cases, the solution can be constructed using analytical methods, but in more complex situations, for example motion under resistance, you will use numerical methods to find the motion of a particle.

content_sections.Module Description:
The module combines two important topics in preparation for your future studies. 

Probability is the study of the chance of events occurring. It has important applications to understand the likelihood of multiple events happening together in order to make rational decisions. You will be introduced to Kolmogorov’s modern axiomatic theory of probability and the concept of random variables. You will study both discrete and continuous random variables. Finally, will explore two applications of probability: reliability theory (which looks at the likelihood of the failure of a piece of equipment at some point in the future) and Markov chains (which model how the likelihood of being in different states evolves in time).

Multivariable calculus extends concepts of calculus to functions of more than one variable. This leads to the idea of partial derivatives. You will learn how to differentiate functions of more than one variable, and how to do integrals of such functions along curves and over areas. You will also learn how to change coordinates in multiple integrals using Jacobians, and study Green's theorem in the plane.

Calculus is the mathematical study of rates of change. It underpins much of applied mathematics, since we are often interested in determining how quickly things will change, whether that is looking at changes in space or in time.

You will start this module by studying complex numbers and vectors. (These topics are not strictly calculus but will be needed in calculus later on.) You will then study differentiation – how to determine the rate of change of one variable or function as another variable changes. You will meet the formal definition of the derivative, and discover how to differentiate from first principles, before learning various rules and techniques for differentiating more complex functions. You will also learn about applications to curve sketching and power series.

Next you will study integration (the inverse of differentiation), learning various techniques, including substitution and integration by parts, and considering applications to finding areas and arc lengths. You will then learn about methods for solving first and second-order ordinary differential equations. Techniques covered here include reduction of order. and integrating factors. You will learn how to use the computer program Maple to solve differential equations numerically.

This module provides an introduction to various fundamental mathematical concepts and techniques that you will need to study more advanced mathematics later in your degree.

You will gain a thorough introduction to some systems of numbers commonly found in Mathematics including: natural numbers, integers, rational numbers and real numbers. You will also learn about common set-theoretic notation and terminology, and a precise language with which to talk about functions. There is emphasis on precise definitions of concepts and careful proofs of results, which will prepare you for doing the same in future mathematics modules. You will study different techniques of mathematical proof, including: proof by induction, direct proofs, proof by contradiction, contrapositive statements, equivalent statements, the role of examples and counterexamples, and how to deal with “there exists” and “for all” statements.

You will explore the mathematical notion of a limit, which is the start of the branch of mathematics known as analysis. You will see the precise definition of the limit of a sequence of real numbers, and learn how to prove that a sequence converges to a limit. After studying limits of infinite sequences, you will move on to studying series, which capture the notion of an infinite sum, and learn techniques to prove that a series converges.

This module covers two distinct topics that will underpin a lot of your further studies on your degree.

In the Linear Equations part, you will learn about the theory of matrices. You will study: matrix operations; the relationship between matrices and systems of linear equations; how determinants can help tell whether a system of equations has just one solution; eigenvalues and eigenvectors, which give directions where a matrix behaves just as a contraction or expansion; and geometric interpretations of all these. 

In the Digital Skills part, you will learn how modern computer software including AI can be used to help in the study and communication of mathematics.  You will also learn how to produce mathematical documents using a typesetting system called “LaTeX”, and how to solve mathematical problems computationally using both symbolic algebra software and Excel.

content_sections.Module Description:
This module comprises two distinct parts, building on the Analysis and Algebra streams you studied in first year.

Linear Algebra follows on from the study of the concrete examples of vectors and matrices, to the abstract notions of a vector space and linear transformations between them. The power of this abstraction is that it allows the theory to be applied in many more situations: Linear Algebra underpins much of modern mathematics and is used in most sciences. You will learn what an abstract vector space is and its basic properties: in particular, how to make precise the notion of dimension by studying their bases. You will then look at linear transformation between vector spaces, including their kernel and image and the Rank-Nullity Theorem. You will see how, by fixing bases, a linear transformation can be encoded in matrix form, and how changing the bases changes that matrix. This will then allow you to study eigenvectors and the diagonalization of linear transformations.

In Analysis, you will cover the basic theory of functions of the complex plane, building on the theory of real functions. As well as being of intrinsic interest, complex functions are important for many applications in applied mathematics and beyond. While continuous complex functions behave in a similar way to real functions, you will learn how differentiability brings surprising extra constraints and rigidity, including the so-called Cauchy–Riemann equations. You will also study how power series can be used to represent functions, making precise the Taylor series seen in Calculus.

content_sections.Module Description:
This module comprises two distinct parts, building on Complex Functions and Group Theory respectively.

Complex Integration is a beautiful theory extending integration to complex functions: rather than integrating over an interval of real numbers, you will learn to integrate along a path in the complex plane. The theory you will see often allows these integrals to be done without calculus: instead, the Residue Theorem says it is enough to understand the function at a few specific points (the singularities of the function). This is especially important in applications in Applied Mathematics. This theory also allows you to calculate some real integrals which cannot be computed using real methods alone, as well as infinite series. Along the way, you will also see how Cauchy’s Theorem leads to the result that, in a certain sense, all differentiable complex functions are given by power series – which is not true for real functions.

Ring Theory is the study of mathematical structures like the integers, where we have good notions of addition and multiplication (as opposed to a group, where we only have one of these). Similar structures abound in mathematics so it is useful to see how much the theory of the integers can be extended to other rings – for example, factorization into primes, division with remainder and substitution. You will learn the basic theory of rings, including the notion of an ideal in a ring and its quotient ring, and study a variety of examples including polynomial rings.

content_sections.Module Description:
In applied mathematics, you will often need to solve equations involving derivatives of the unknown function that you are trying to find. Such equations are known as “differential equations”, and you will learn about various techniques for solving them in this module. 

When the unknown quantity is a function of one variable then the equation is known as an “ordinary differential equation”. While you will already have seen some techniques of solving ordinary differential equations, you will see  new techniques such as  series solutions and the method of Frobenius.  When the unknown quantity is a function more than one variable then the equation is known as a “partial differential equation” and the method of separation of variables will be introduced. Solutions involving Fourier series (representations of functions as infinite series involving trigonometric functions) are also considered. You will encounter a variety of important partial differential equations from applied mathematics, including heat equation, the wave equation, and Laplace’s equation. 

You will then move on to study two methods that can be used to solve problems that occur in applied mathematics. Fourier transforms can be used to solve ordinary differential equations, partial differential equations, and integral equations. The method of characteristics is a particular technique for solving partial differential equations by converting them to ordinary differential equations.  

Finally, you will learn about techniques for analysing collections of coupled differential equations known as “dynamical systems”, which describe how certain variables evolve in time. The techniques here will help you analyse and understand the behaviour of nonlinear differential equations and acts as a starting point for the study of chaos.

In this module you will consider how to model the flow of liquids and gases using mathematics. Understanding fluid flows is important for weather predictions, the aerodynamics of air flow round a car, and understanding why planes are able to stay in the air.

You will first study the fundamentals of “vector calculus”, which deals with how differentiation can be applied to vectors fields (vectors that vary in space), such as the velocity of a fluid. You will then apply your knowledge of vector calculus to see how we formulate the differential equations that govern fluid flows. You will go on to solve simple fluid-flow problems, such as the determining the rate of flow out of a reservoir. 

You will then examine how computers can solve differential equations and approximate continuous functions. This will involve studying the underlying algorithms relevant to understanding fluid flow, and also some practical programming using Python to study the motion of systems of vortices through a fluid.

In the final part of the module, you will learn about how complex variables and functions can be used to solve problems in inviscid fluid flow, using what is known as “complex potentials”. This represents a nice application of some theory from pure mathematics in an applied mathematics context.  The methods you will study can be used, for example, to estimate the lift on an aerofoil.

content_sections.Module Description:
The weather affects everyone and influences decisions that are made continuously around the world. From designing and siting a wind farm to assessing flood risk and public safety, weather plays a vital role. 

Have you ever wondered what actually causes the weather we experience, for example why large storms are so frequent across north western Europe, especially in Winter? In this module you will learn the fundamentals of the science of meteorology. We will concentrate on the physical processes that underpin the radiation balance, thermodynamics, wind-flow, atmospheric stability, weather systems and the water cycle. We will link these to the weather we experience throughout the Semester. You will learn how weather is a rich fusion of descriptive and numerical elements and you will be able to draw effectively on your own skill strengths while practising and developing others, such that by the end of the module you will understand regional and spatial variations in weather patterns.

content_sections.Module Description:
Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are ubiquitous in applied mathematics. They arise in many models of physical systems where there is coupling between the variation in space and time, or more than one spatial dimension. Examples include fluid flows, electromagnetism, population dynamics, and the spread on infectious diseases. It is therefore important to understand the theory of PDEs, as well as different analytic and numerical methods for solving them.

This module will provide you with an understanding of the different types of PDE, including linear, non-linear, elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic; and how these features affect the required boundary conditions and solution techniques. We will study different methods of analytical solution (such as greens functions, boundary-integral methods, similarity solutions, and characteristics); as well as appropriate numerical methods (with topics such as implicit versus explicit schemes, convergence and stability). Examples and applications will be taken from a variety of fields.

content_sections.Module Description:
Number Theory is the study of arithmetical properties of the integers: properties of, and patterns in, prime numbers, integer solutions of equations with integer coefficients, etc. Gauss called Number Theory "The Queen of Mathematics" and, following on from work of Fermat and Euler, is responsible for the emergence of Number Theory as a central subject in modern mathematics. Since then, Number Theory has developed in many directions, including Algebraic, Analytic and Probabilistic Number Theory, and Diophantine Geometry, and has found surprising applications in modern life (notably in Cryptography). 

In this module, building on previous material on prime factorization and congruences, and second year material on groups, rings and fields, you will study various aspects of Number Theory, including certain Diophantine equations and patterns in primes.

content_sections.Module Description:
Fluid dynamics concerns the mathematical modelling of the flow of liquids and
gases. It has wide ranging applications across nature, engineering, and biology.
Applications include understanding the behaviour of ocean waves and weather,
designing efficient aircraft and ships, and describing the flow of blood around the
body.

Waves are a general physical phenomenon that allow the transfer of energy from one
place to another without the net transfer of matter. Fluids can support waves
through a variety of different mechanisms. Two common examples are gravity waves
in the surface of a body of water, and sound waves travelling through compressible
liquid or gas.

In this module, you will study aspects of linear and nonlinear waves using analytical
techniques. You will also consider mathematical models of fluids, particularly
including viscosity (or stickiness) of a fluid. Illustrated by practical examples, you
will develop the governing differential Navier-Stokes equations, and then consider
their solution either finding exact solutions, or using analytical techniques to obtain
solutions in certain limits (for example low viscosity or high viscosity).

content_sections.Module Description:
General relativity is the modern understanding of the physics of gravity, and is required to describe strong-gravity physics - like that of black holes - which cannot be explained with Newtonian gravity.  Beginning with special relativity, this module teaches the physical reasoning and mathematics (e.g. metrics and tensors) that lead to the equations of general relativity.  You will learn about the importance of general relativity in astrophysics - such as black holes, neutron stars, and gravitational waves - and some of the ways in which general relativity has been tested.

If taking this module, you will not later be able to take PHY-7007A, which covers the same material together with more advanced topics.

content_sections.Module Description: We trace the development of mathematics from prehistory to the high cultures of old Egypt, Mesopotamia and the Valley of Ind, through Islamic mathematics onto the mathematical modernity through a selection of results from the present time. We present the rise of calculus from the first work of the Indian and Greek mathematicians’ differentiation and integration through at the time of Newton and Leibniz. We discuss mathematical logic, the ideas of propositions, the axiomatisation of mathematics, and the idea of quantifiers. Our style is to explore mathematical practice and conceptual developments in different historical and geographic contexts.

content_sections.Module Description:
You will gain an understanding of how science is disseminated to the public and explore the theories surrounding learning and communication. You will investigate science as a culture and how this culture interfaces with the public. Examining case studies in a variety of different scientific areas, alongside looking at how information is released in scientific literature and subsequently picked up by the public press, will give you an understanding of science communication. You will gain an appreciation of how science information can be used to change public perception and how it can sometimes be misinterpreted. You will also learn practical skills by designing, running and evaluating a public outreach event at a school or in a public area.

If you wish to take this module you will be required to write a statement of selection. These statements will be assessed and students will be allocated to the module accordingly.

In terms of data analysis, we will focus on regression and classification algorithms to build prediction models. Through this module, you will gain knowledge of algorithms and methods for data analysis, as well as practical experience programming in Python using popular libraries such as Numpy, Pandas, Polars, Scikit-learn, Matplotlib and Seaborne.

This module provides a broad understanding of the core topics and issues relating to the rapidly evolving world of cyber security. As security becomes an increasingly important part of our daily lives, then it is essential to develop an understanding of the theories of security and their application to the wider world.

The module prepares you with essential knowledge and understanding of cyber security and provides the tools for further study and research in specialist areas.

content_sections.Module Description:
The ocean is a dynamic component of the Earth system and plays a critical role in the modulation of our climate by both transporting excess heat from the equator to the poles and drawing down carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. It is also important economically through commercial fisheries, internationally shipping, and renewable energy developments such as offshore wind farms. 

In this module you will explore the fundamental physical processes that drive global ocean circulation, building on concepts introduced in the first-year module Earth Systems. You will find out how the ocean interacts with the overlying atmosphere and together help modulate our climate. You will also explore the different set of physical processes that dominate circulation in the shallow seas that surround the continents, including how they drive biogeochemical fluxes and primary productivity. 

Career development: You will develop new skills during this module that will support careers in the marine renewable energy industry, environmental consultancy, government laboratories, and academia. Applied aspects of the module will be taught by guest lecturers from the Centre for Environment Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas), through the Collaborative Centre for Sustainable Use of the Seas.

content_sections.Module Description:
The weather affects everyone and influences decisions that are made continuously around the world. From designing and siting a wind farm to assessing flood risk and public safety, weather plays a vital role. 

Have you ever wondered what actually causes the weather we experience, for example why large storms are so frequent across north western Europe, especially in Winter? In this module you will learn the fundamentals of the science of meteorology. We will concentrate on the physical processes that underpin the radiation balance, thermodynamics, wind-flow, atmospheric stability, weather systems and the water cycle. We will link these to the weather we experience throughout the Semester. You will learn how weather is a rich fusion of descriptive and numerical elements and you will be able to draw effectively on your own skill strengths while practising and developing others, such that by the end of the module you will understand regional and spatial variations in weather patterns.

content_sections.Module Description:
Our aim is to show how environmental problems may be solved from the initial problem, to mathematical formulation and numerical solution. Problems will be described conceptually, then defined mathematically, then solved numerically via computer programming. 

The module requires some knowledge of calculus, ordinary and partial differential equations, and some experience with coding. Please contact the module organiser if you need more detail on the prerequisites.

The module consists of lectures on numerical methods and computing practicals; the practicals being designed to illustrate the solution of problems using the methods covered in lectures. We will guide you through the solution of a model of an environmental process of your own choosing. The skills developed in this module are very relevant to jobs that involve modelling to better understand and predict natural . processes such as weather forecasting, impact of hazards, effects of climate change and possible outcomes of proposed environmental management scenarios.

content_sections.Module Description:
This module is about the science of weather prediction and climate on timescales from days to multiple decades and is for those interested in furthering their interest or career in climate science or meteorology.

The module covers:  short-term weather forecasting and the relevant important processes, longer-term monthly to seasonal prediction, climate and its variability, and decadal climate prediction. It also considers the differing roles of the atmosphere and ocean as the module moves from shorter to longer timescales, demonstrating a "seamless" way of thinking about weather and climate prediction.  

You will develop a clear understanding of risks and opportunities of weather to people, organisations and to the wider environment. You’ll learn how to confidently source a diverse range of real-time weather information and you’ll practice analysing such data, leading subsequently to successful interpretation and effective communication. You’ll see, first hand, how weather and climate prediction depend upon computer systems for the efficient sharing, processing and visualisation of information. Being taught by weather practitioners and climate scientists with long experience of providing weather and climate services to users, you will get the inside track on what it’s like to work in weather and climate.

The module is taught using a combination of lectures and practical classes.  It is assessed by one piece of coursework which combines two short essay-style reports with data analysis of a synoptic weather situation, and analysis of how similar situations are projected to change in different parts of the world. 

The module prepares students with skills required for weather forecasting, understanding climate prediction, and contributing to decisions on responses to climate change in both public and private sectors.

content_sections.Module Description: What are the rules that dictate how company accounts should be prepared and why do those rules exist? This is the essence of this module. Whilst company directors may wish to present the financial condition of a business in the best possible light, rules have been developed to protect investors and users of the accounts from being misled. You’ll develop knowledge and skills in understanding and applying accounting standards when preparing financial statements. You will also prepare and analyse statements of both individual businesses and groups of companies. Large UK companies report using International Financial Reporting Standards, and these are the standards that you’ll use. You’ll begin by preparing basic financial statements and progress, preparing accounts of increasing complexity by looking at topics including goodwill, leases, cashflow statements, foreign currency transactions, financial instruments and group accounts. You will also deepen your analytical skills through ratio analysis. You’ll learn through a mixture of lectures, seminars and self-study, and be assessed by one three-hour examination. On successful completion of this module, you’ll have acquired significant technical skills in both the preparation and analysis of financial statements. This will give you a strong basis from which to build if you are planning on a career in business or accounting.

content_sections.Module Description:
Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are ubiquitous in applied mathematics. They arise in many models of physical systems where there is coupling between the variation in space and time, or more than one spatial dimension. Examples include fluid flows, electromagnetism, population dynamics, and the spread of infectious diseases. It is therefore important to understand the theory of PDEs, as well as different analytic and numerical methods for solving them.

This module will provide you with an understanding of the different types of PDE, including linear, non-linear, elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic; and how these features affect the required boundary conditions and solution techniques. We will study different methods of analytical solution (such as greens functions, boundary-integral methods, similarity solutions, and characteristics); as well as appropriate numerical methods (with topics such as implicit versus explicit schemes, convergence, and stability). Examples and applications will be taken from a variety of fields.

For the advanced topics, you will study similarity solutions and implicit numerical methods for non-linear PDES.

content_sections.Module Description:
Number Theory is the study of arithmetical properties of the integers: properties of, and patterns in, prime numbers, integer solutions of equations with integer coefficients, etc. Gauss called Number Theory "The Queen of Mathematics" and, following on from work of Fermat and Euler, is responsible for the emergence of Number Theory as a central subject in modern mathematics. Since then, Number Theory has developed in many directions, including Algebraic, Analytic and Probabilistic Number Theory, and Diophantine Geometry, and has found surprising applications in modern life (notably in Cryptography). 

In this module, building on previous material on prime factorization and congruences, and second year material on groups, rings and fields, you will study various aspects of Number Theory, including certain Diophantine equations and patterns in primes.

For the advanced topics, you will study applications of Number Theory to Cryptography. Important cryptographic methods like RSA rely on the computational difficulty of factorizing large integers into primes. You will learn some techniques, based on the Number Theory you have learnt, to attack this factorizing problem.

content_sections.Module Description:
Fluid dynamics concerns the mathematical modelling of the flow of liquids and gases. It has wide ranging applications across nature, engineering, and biology.  Applications include understanding the behaviour of ocean waves and weather, designing efficient aircraft and ships, and describing the flow of blood around the body.

Waves are a general physical phenomenon that allow the transfer of energy from one place to another without the net transfer of matter. Fluids can support waves through a variety of different mechanisms. Two common examples are gravity waves in the surface of a body of water, and sound waves travelling through compressible liquid or gas.

In this module, you will study aspects of linear and nonlinear waves using analytical techniques. You will also consider mathematical models of fluids, particularly including viscosity (or stickiness) of a fluid. Illustrated by practical examples, you will develop the governing differential Navier-Stokes equations, and then consider their solution either finding exact solutions, or using analytical techniques to obtain solutions in certain limits (for example low viscosity or high viscosity)

content_sections.Module Description:
General relativity is the modern understanding of the physics of gravity, and is required to describe strong-gravity physics - like that of black holes - which cannot be explained with Newtonian gravity.  Beginning with special relativity, this module teaches the physical reasoning and mathematics (e.g. metrics and tensors) that lead to the equations of general relativity.  You will learn about the importance of general relativity in astrophysics - such as black holes, neutron stars, and gravitational waves - and some of the ways in which general relativity has been tested.

Some of the material in this module is co-taught with PHY-6007A (general relativity); you may not take both. In this level-7 version you will also learn more advanced topics, including a greater focus on astrophysical phenomena where general relativity is important.
